source: Research Paper – Based on 'Online Portfolios for Career Development: A Review' by Hains-Wesson et al.

research_paper.title: Online Portfolios for Career Development: A Review
research_paper.authors: R. Hains-Wesson, M. Wakeling, et al.

level_1: Research papers explain how online portfolios help students show real skills.
Studies show portfolios help employers trust a candidate’s coding ability.
In this module, students learn why sharing projects publicly makes a difference.
Papers say portfolios are better proof than just grades or certificates.
Researchers suggest portfolios make students feel more job ready.
level_2: The paper reviews how students use GitHub and personal websites for portfolios.
It shows clear README files and docs help recruiters understand your work.
In this module, students learn to write instructions and add screenshots.
The study says portfolios should be updated often, not left stale.
It also explains that public code shows soft skills like communication.
level_3: Research discusses how open source work boosts credibility.
Papers say portfolios show self-driven learning beyond school.
In this module, students practice advanced projects with real use cases.
The paper highlights linking projects with LinkedIn or resumes.
It also explains how employers look for unique or niche projects.
level_4: Research suggests mentors should guide juniors on portfolio strategies.
Papers discuss teamwork skills shown through group repos.
This module pushes students to maintain repos and handle issues.
The study explains community-backed projects build trust faster.
It encourages students to share portfolio stories in blogs and talks.
